WORLD TOUR
AS THE EYES OF THE WORLD TURN TOWARD AFRICA AND ASIA, TEACHERS ARE
SEARCHING FOR AUTHENTIC MATERIAL ABOUT THESE STRANGE AND DISTANT
LANDS, TO HELP SATISFY THIS NEED IN St. LOUIS, KSLH HAS PRODUCED
A NEW RADIO SERIES CALLED WORLD TOUR WHICH BRINGS SCHOOL CHILDREN
THE VOICE OF A NATIVE OF THE PUNJAB, INDIA, A MEMBER OF A NATURAL
SCIENCE EXPEDITION TO KENYA, OR A PROFESSOR IN JOHANNESBURG, SOUTH
Africa,
Preliminary to the actual writing of the programs, members of the
Elementary Social Studies Radio Planning Committee and a group of
sixth grade teachers met after school hours to outline the series
AND DO SOME OF THE NECESSARY RESEARCH. It WAS DECIDED TO USE A
DOCUMENTARY FORMAT.
Three sources of material made such a format possible: one, tapes
WHICH HAVE COME TO KSLH THROUGH THE NAEB NETWORK* TWO, BACKLOG OF
RECORDINGS MADE IN KSLH STUDIOS* AND THREE, LIVE RECORDINGS OF LO¬
CAL TRAVELERS OR FOREIGN VISITORS TAPED IN St. LOUIS DURING THE
CONTENT OF WORLD TOUR. THE EXCERPTS SELECTED WERE THOSE WHICH BEST
FITTED THE DEMANDS OF THE SERIES AND WHICH MOST EFFECTIVELY SUPPLE¬
MENTED THE SIXTH GRADE COURSE OF STUDY.
The KDKA "African Adventure" series proved to be very helpful, Vicki
Corey’s recordings of native music, brief conversations with local
PERSONALITIES SUCH AS GRIFFITH DAVIS, TECHNICAL ADVISER ON THE POINT
program in Liberia, and a firsthand description of her descent
into a Capetown gold mine fitted into the series nicely.
Some of the recordings which KSLH had on hand were interviews with
VISITORS MADE AT THE STATION. THESE INCLUDED MICHAEL PENNINGTON,
AN INSTRUCTOR AT $T. JOHN’S SCHOOL IN JOHANNESBURG, Dr. PlNAR, A
PROFESSOR AT THE UNIVERSITY OF JOHANNESBURG, AND MlSS EAST, A TEACHER
at Sueing Mission in the interior of Liberia.
